title: Celeb X Factor's Martin Bashir on harrowing upbringing that inspired him to sing
text:

Martin Bashir is better known as the hard nosed journalist who has secured some of the most coveted interviews ever.

From Princess Diana to Michael Jackson, the news man has never been afraid to ask the hard questions.

But now the 56-year-old has set his sights on the X Factor crown - and has revealed how his tough upbringing ignited his passion for singing.

On his first appearance on the ITV show Martin made the heartbreaking confession that his late brother was the driving force behind his decision to take part.

Tommy was just 29 when he lost his battle against Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a lifelong muscle wasting illness that is always fatal.

(Image: Dymond/Thames/Syco/REX)

Martin and his mum had cared for him all of his life and the family were devastated when he passed away in 1991.

The interviewer said in the first Celebrity X Factor: "When you grow up with a child and you fight over toys at four and he never fights back and then, by the time he is 13 he can’t feed himself, you feel that you have no excuse for turning down opportunities.”

He also heartbreakingly revealed that every time he doubts himself before taking on a new task, his brother is his inspiration.

Martin said: "Every time I have faced a challenge I have heard him whispering saying, ‘What excuse do you have? You have no excuse.

“‘You have never sung but someone has come to you and said, ‘Give it a shot’. And that is my motivation’.”

(Image: Martin Bashir)

Even Simon Cowell was moved by Martin's story, telling him "it is always about the person and the story and we related to your story".

And despite joking he sounded "like a constipated donkey", Martin's love of singing stems from his tough childhood.

He grew up on council estates in London and even spent the first nine months of his life in a homeless shelter when a blaze destroyed the family home.

Until he was 11, Martin and his family lived in a tiny flat in Wandsworth, south London, before moving to another council estate nearby.

But despite the lack of money, music and fun were always a key part of his life.

(Image: PA)

A Jamaican family lived in the flat above the Bashir's tiny home and would play world music every Saturday night, something Martin describes as "utterly mesmerising".

By the late 60s he was hooked on reggae after growing up in what he calls the "golden age".

Artists like Larry Marshall, Delroy Wilson, Gregory Isaacs and Dennis Brown fuelled what he describes as his "lifelong passion for music".

So when Martin was offered the opportunity to appear on the X Factor, he jumped at the chance.

But he admits it hasn't been without its challenges.

Martin said: "As I have discovered over the last few months, it's a privilege that comes with considerable pressure.

"The experience has been one of the most challenging of my life. Good singing is hard work and has required a willingness to be vulnerable and potentially exposed as an outright failure."
description: The interviewer also has a heartbreaking reason for taking part in the hit ITV show
